ANNEX

Questions to the Council
Question no 18 by Richard Howitt (H-0515/99)
 Subject: NGOs and the European employment strategy
 

With reference to the recently published draft Employment Guidelines, does the Council accept that NGOs should be recognised as partners in the European employment strategy? What specific proposals will the President table at the EU Summit in Helsinki on 8-9 December?

 
  
 

Article 128 of the EC Treaty states that the Council will listen to, inter alia, the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions before taking decisions on employment strategy in Europe, which includes, for example, approving guidelines on employment. In this way NGOs also have the opportunity to prepare guidelines on employment. The Council believes it is important, however, that all players at all levels should contribute to the success of the strategy in their own countries. It is clear that NGOs involved in issues of employment, including those that focus on, for example, promoting employment opportunities for the disabled or issues of equality, can have an impact at both regional and local level. All must play their part in the implementation of guidelines on employment.

I would like, furthermore, to draw the honourable Member’s attention to the fact that, although employers and unions are not NGOs in the conventional sense, they must be regarded from the start as being able to exert an important influence on employment strategy in Europe.

The Standing Committee on Employment, which was originally set up in 1970, was reorganised to make its work more effective, by increasing the influence employers and unions have in particular(1). Its next meeting is planned for November 11, i.e., the day before the Labour/Social Affairs Council meets on 12 November, at which the Ministers will examine the Commission’s employment package for 1999 – 2000 in detail.

In addition, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs will also listen to employers and unions before it drafts its own opinion on a proposal for guidelines on employment in the year 2000. The Committee on Employment, to be set up on the basis of Article 130 of the EC Treaty, will replace the present Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. A new committee will also listen to employers and unions on matters of employment, on the basis of Article 130.

As for preparations for the European Council in Helsinki, the European Council will, in general, reconfirm in its conclusions its support for the political agreement on guidelines that it should achieve in its joint sitting (labour and social affairs / Ecofin) on 19 November 1999.

A jointly drafted report on employment will be presented on 10 – 11 December 1999 to a meeting of the European Council.

 
 

(1) Council Decision 1999/207/EC of 9 March 1999 on the reform of the Standing Committee on Employment and the abrogation of Decision No 70/532/EEC

 

Question no 19 by Pernille Frahm (H-0526/99)
 Subject: Echelon
 

The STOA report entitled 'Development of surveillance, technology and risk of abuse of economic information' (PE 168.184/Part 3/4) gives cause for grave concern over the current situation in which communications may be tapped without a warrant.

What are the Council’s views on the protection of private and commercial communications against eavesdropping without a warrant by Echelon, for example?

 
  
 

On the question of the protection of privacy in the field of telecommunications, the Council would remind you of the European Parliament’s and the Council’s directive of 15 December 1997 concerning the treatment of personal information and the protection of privacy in the field of telecommunications.

The Council has already answered a number of Parliament’s questions about Echelon. The Council would remind you that all Member States have ratified the European Convention on the Protection of Human Rights and Basic Freedoms and that the Treaty of the European Union refers to the protection of human rights as one of the cornerstones of the European Union.

 

Question no 20 by Niall Andrews (H-0527/99)
 Subject: East Timor
 

Will the Council state what action it proposes to take to comply with the terms of the resolution adopted by Parliament on East Timor at its plenary session of 13-17 September 1999?

 
  
 

The Council shares the concern shown in the resolution of the European Council on the situation in East Timor, and especially the atrocities that have occurred in the region since the results of the referendum were made known. Ministers have debated the issue repeatedly in recent weeks, and the Union has been very glad to see the formation of INTERFET, and has thanked the countries that have become members of it.

The Council declared in its adopted resolution of 13 September that it wishes to see the East Timorese nation achieve freely chosen independence. The Member States expect to be able to recognise East Timor when the independence process has been decided on. As the honourable Member knows, the Council agreed, in the same context, to an export ban on weapons, ammunition, and military supplies to Indonesia, and a ban on delivering such supplies as might be used for purposes of internal oppression or terrorism. Both bans are to last four years. In addition, it agreed to cease bilateral military cooperation with Indonesia, also for a period of four years. The Council also supported the call for a meeting of the UN Commission on Human Rights and, after that, the Union in a meeting moved for a resolution that would propose sending an international team to investigate alleged violations of international humanitarian law. The Commission has informed the Council of the existence of two batches of humanitarian aid, the first being two million euros, and the second, three million euros.

The resolution adopted by the European Parliament in September raised two essential questions: the acceptance of a common position on economic aid and the reconstruction of civil society and the reservation of a separate East Timor appropriation in the budget for the year 2000. The Council is prepared to investigate all the instruments at its disposal to promote the objectives of the Union in East Timor, and the possibility of joint action is not at all excluded.

 

Question no 21 by Liam Hyland (H-0530/99)
 Subject: The family farm
 

Will the President-in-Office outline the current thinking in relation to the importance of the family farm and what new initiatives, if any, the Council would support to maintain and promote the family farm?

 
  
 

The Council has long been attentive to the issues of family farms. It is well aware of the need to preserve and promote family farming. An indication of this is the current application of the legislation in force on improving the effectiveness of agricultural structures.

It has primarily come to my attention that family farms are one of the basic aspects of the multiform European agricultural model. This model plays a central role in the reforms of the common agricultural policy. The Council has firmly decided to continue developing this model and thus safeguard the future of family farms, as it emphasised recently in its conclusions on the millennium round of negotiations. This requires action to be started to strengthen the special qualities of the model, both in the European Union and outside it.

I would also like to remind the honourable Member that the policy on the development of rural areas, which the Council recently decided on in connection with the Agenda 2000 talks, will, in the future, form the Second Pillar of the CAP. This policy, as laid down in Council Regulation No 1257/99, will strengthen the legislation that exists for this sector and the measures included in it. These measures are there to endeavour to ensure the viability of family farms, encourage young farmers to embark on the profession, promote their training, facilitate recommencement of farming, and generally strengthen the social/professional networks in the rural areas.

The Council considers that this new policy of supporting rural areas offers farming families a chance to develop, taking account of the problems of preserving and developing family farms, and, at the same time, is an attempt to rid rural residents of the most common problems that they face.

This being the case, the Council believes that the decisions taken on rural development were an appropriate response to the problems of family farm viability and dynamics.

 

Question no 22 by Mihail Papayannakis (H-0532/99)
 Subject: Ban on Greek schools operating in Albania
 

The Albanian Ministry of Education has decided to ban Greek schools from operating in Himarë and Përmet despite declarations by the Albanian Government concerning the rights of the Greek minority. This action constitutes a violation of the constitutional right of the Greek community to be educated in their mother tongue, a right that has been endorsed by the International Court of The Hague.

Given that in 1993 the Albanian Government adopted a constitutional law on human rights, Article 26 of which refers to the rights of minorities, given that the Council has stated that the EU promotes moves to find a solution to the problems facing ethnic groups on the basis of the principles of the state of law and the international obligations of the parties concerned and given finally that acts of this kind expose Albania to criticism from the international community and do nothing to further friendly relations and cooperation between Albania and Greece and Albania and the EU, will the Council say whether it intends to intervene to persuade the Albanian authorities to respect all the principles, democratic laws and human rights which constitute the basis for institutional relations between Albania and the EU and enable all members of the Greek minority to enjoy the fundamental right to be taught in and learn their mother tongue?

 
  
 

Respect for democratic principles, human rights and the rights of minorities are important conditions to be fulfilled by the countries of the Western Balkans region when it comes to the development of bilateral relations with the European Union. As a country eligible for a Stabilisation and Association Agreement, Albania’s performance in these areas is of particular importance to the EU.

The Council reviews compliance by the countries of the region with such conditions on a regular basis. The next review is currently scheduled for November 1999.

According to the Council’s information, no Greek school has been closed in the villages of Himarë and Përmet. The only schools operating in these two villages are public schools in which Albanian is the compulsory language. However, 30 Greek families have called upon the Albanian Ministry of Education to set up a separate class in Greek in the public school of these villages. The Presidency is aware of the fact that this matter has also been taken up by the Greek organisation defending the interests of the Greek minority in Albania, Omonia.

Our information is, on the other side that the Albanian Government is trying to do its best to solve the problem. All of us should have, also in this case, some consideration for the very difficult situation it faces at all levels, in particular the economic level, with the lowest rate of GDP per inhabitant, or the internal security level, with major problems notably in the South of the country where the problems raised by the Honourable Parliamentarian are of peculiar acuteness.

Our information is that the Albanian Government is currently looking for a practical and legal solution to the problem of setting up Greek classes in a public school.

 

Question no 23 by John Walls Cushnahan (H-0534/99)
 Subject: Policy planning and early warning unit
 

In the light of recent events in East Timor, will the Council give an assurance that the establishment of a policy planning and early warning unit, as envisaged under the Amsterdam Treaty, will be given top priority?

Furthermore, will the respective parliamentary committees be provided with the relevant analyses, recommendations and strategies on potential crises?

 
  
 

Recent events, including those in East Timor, show how essential it is for the European Union to have a viable common foreign and security policy. During our presidential term, we have also paid special attention to how effective and consistent the Union’s external activity is.

The new Secretary General of the Council, Javier Solana, who is also a high-ranking advocate of the common foreign and security policy, begins his duties, under the Treaty of Amsterdam, on 18 October 1999. One of his first tasks will be to get the work of a planning and early warning unit under way under the auspices of the Secretary General of the Council. The necessary preparatory work is already under way.

As for your second question, I can state that we support the communication that exists between the Council and the European Parliament, by virtue of the provisions of the Treaty of Amsterdam, and the exchange of information and views between the highly placed representative and the European Parliament.

 

Question no 24 by Olle Schmidt (H-0536/99)
 Subject: Principle of public access to official documents in Sweden
 

In connection with negotiations for Swedish membership of the European Union, the Swedish Government proclaimed that Swedish policy was that the principle of public access to official documents and freedom to provide information would continue to apply if Sweden joined. Accordingly, a Swedish declaration to that effect was added to the act of accession.

The Swedish Agency for Administrative Development has now conducted a survey among Swedish government agencies. The survey has not yet been fully analysed but preliminary reports indicate that government agencies in other Member States have tried to persuade Swedish agencies not to make public documents which would normally be in the public domain under the principle of freedom of access. In its reply to the survey, the National Food Administration, for example, states that other countries' embassies have contacted the agency and complained about the fact that Sweden has freedom of access to official documents and the nuisance it causes. What does the Council intend to do in response to this situation?

 
  
 

The Council has repeatedly made it known publicly that it considers the principle of transparency to be important, and that it will strive to ensure it plays a role in its day-to-day work.

However, the Council is not familiar with the circumstances of the case the honourable Member refers to. Under Article 255 of the EC Treaty, the Council must, in the course of the two years from the entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam, reconfirm the common principles and restrictions that relate to the right recorded in the Treaty to have access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents. Although the forthcoming act on transparency does not directly concern the facts of the case the honourable member mentions in his question, it will nonetheless serve to clarify the position regarding public accessibility to documents in the Union. The Council cannot, however, act before the Commission has produced a proposal for an act on transparency. Let us hope this happens as soon as possible.

 

Question no 25 by Nigel Paul Farage (H-0539/99)
 Subject: Potential UK share in ECB equity
 

Will the Council please clarify what the United Kingdom's potential share of the ECB's equity would be, both in percentage terms and the exact figure involved?

 
  
 

According to Article 28 of the ECB Statute, the overall capital of the ECB amounts to EUR 5 billion. Applying the formula for Member States’ subscriptions set out in Article 29.1 of the ESCB Statute, the share of the Bank of England in the ECB’s capital is 14.6811 per cent.

Article 48 of the ESCB Statute provides that non-participating Member States should pay up only a minimal percentage of their capital subscriptions as a contribution to the operational costs of the ECB, if the ECB General Council so decides. In accordance with this Article, non-euro area central banks were each required to pay up 5% of their subscribed capital share.

In the UK’s case, this amounted to EURO (36,702,750), offset against proceeds received from the liquidation of the EMI.

 

Question no 26 by Ioannis Theonas (H-0540/99)
 Subject: Risk of loss of human life from unexploded bombs scattered throughout Yugoslavia
 

A WHO investigation has found that 150 people have been killed or maimed by unexploded bombs scattered throughout Yugoslavia and, in particular, Kosovo, following the 78-day NATO bombing campaign which used 1,100 cluster bombs containing 220,000 bomblets. Explosive devices are also to be found scattered around neighbouring regions, as well as in the sea, which have also caused death and mutilation.

What measures will the Council take to deal immediately with the problem of the bombs and mines left behind by the murderous bombing campaign so that we are not left to mourn other deaths and injuries, particularly in Yugoslavia and the Adriatic?

 
  
 

The honourable Member will certainly know that the matter has already been discussed in the Council. The Council took a decision on 9 November 1998, based on Article J.4(2) of the Treaty on European Union, on practical arrangements between the European Union and the Western European Union for assistance in mine clearance in the Croatia region. The Council receives a report every month on how the aid action is progressing.

The European Union is involved in solving this serious problem. It has already granted five million euros to humanitarian mine clearance operations in Kosovo, and is also considering additional funding. It is worth remembering, however, that the problem does not concern the European Union exclusively. Other agencies also, such as NATO and the United Nations, are committed to solving the problems of unexploded bombs and other explosives in the Kosovo and Adriatic regions.

The European Union, in its own work, is focusing for the present on plans to reconstruct Kosovo and restore conditions there to their former state. The Council still believes, however, that it is a precondition of any action the European Union takes in the Yugoslavian region that substantial improvements have been made in the political situation there.

 

Question no 27 by Efstratios Korakas (H-0544/99)
 Subject: Failure to alert citizens to the dangers of cultivating genetically modified organisms
 

While EU consumers are becoming increasingly cautious about, and opposed to, genetically modified products, the European Union has so far failed to take any measures to ban them: in adopting this approach it is putting the interests of the multinationals before those of the consumer.

Will the Council say what measures it intends to take to satisfy the demands of European consumers that public health be protected, that consumers be fully informed with a clear indication of the use of genetically modified organisms in products, that imports of banned products and the companies importing them or using the products be subject to prosecution and finally, that the introduction of modified products in the food chain be prohibited?

 
  
 

The Council is fully aware of the importance of the honourable Member’s question and debated the issue in its sitting of 24 – 25 June 1999, at which it achieved consensus on a common position concerning an amendment to European Parliament and Council Directive, by which Directive 90/220/EEC on the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms would be amended.

The following matters have to be taken into consideration. Firstly, before anything is done to instigate procedures for introducing permits into the market, there has to be an assessment, made on the basis of common principles, of the harm caused to the environment and people’s health. The criteria to be followed have to be strengthened and broadened with reference to the directive in force. Secondly, clear and unambiguous labelling will be compulsory at all stages of the produce coming onto the market. Thirdly, further information on genetic modifications is available, furthermore, from the Community register, which is maintained within the framework of the exchange of information between the Commission and the Member States. Fourthly, demands on labelling are to be supplemented with legal effect measures on the traceability of GMOs, so that the competent authorities can monitor the appearance of GMOs at each stage while they are on the market. As imports are also included in the process of introducing goods onto the market, the legal effect measures must also cover imports of GMOs. It is primarily the task of the Member States to impose relevant penalties if these regulations are not obeyed.

With these legal effect measures, particularly those concerning labelling, we can supplement the legal effect measures under Regulation (EC) No 258/97 concerning novel foods and novel food ingredients, which is already the situation, for example, with relation to certain strains of maize and soya.

 

Questions to the Commission
Question no 36 by Catherine Taylor (H-0524/99)
 Subject: Late payments on youth programmes
 

What strategies will the Commission be putting in place to tackle the problem of late payments on youth programmes and, more particularly, the Socrates programme?

 
  
 

The Commission is perfectly aware of the problems that delays in payment can pose for project promoters, and especially organisations for young people.

The Commission realises that it is very important for promoters to obtain at least part of the subsidy intended for them as soon as possible and has set up a procedure for payment in two stages. The first payment, forming an advance, usually represents 80% of the subsidy amount, and this is paid in the days following signature of the contract, and always within the six-week time limit to which the Commission is committed for payments to third parties.

The second payment thus forms the balance due, which does not usually exceed 20% of the total subsidy. The aim of rapid payment of the balance is more difficult to fulfil, because settlement cannot be completed until the Commission has gone through the financial accounts accompanying the promoter's activity report. In this respect there is a need to ensure that speed of payment does not contravene the Commission's legitimate control requirements. The need for proper financial management, the number of projects and the lack of resources may thus cause delays in paying the balance due.

To sum up, the Commission has to satisfy two demands at once: taking account of citizens' interests, and ensuring that payment procedures are properly carried out.

However, we do need to simplify the selection and contracting procedures, to enable promoters to draw as soon as possible on the funds that they have been granted.

The Commission is aware that some procedures are unduly cumbersome, and its proposals for the second generation of the Socrates II, Leonardo da Vinci II and Youth Programmes did recommend a substantial simplification of the procedures concerned which, unfortunately, the Member States did not accept. Parliament has supported the Commission proposal, but so far without success. Indeed, this problem is a point of disagreement between Parliament and the Commission on the one side, and the Council and the Conciliation Committee for the Socrates Programme on the other.

The Commission hopes that when the programmes are finally adopted this mutual concern will be taken into account.

 

Question no 37 by Roy Perry (H-0525/99)
 Subject: Sport in Europe
 

The Commission will be submitting a report on sport to the Helsinki European Council in December 1999. Will the Commission ensure that the report will address the ramifications of increasingly dominant commercial control over sport, in the light, in particular, of such developments as the proposal for a European Super League and the take-over of football clubs by media operators? Will the Commission also ensure that the Parliament is formally consulted on the report before it is presented at the Helsinki Council?

 
  
 

The Commission is aware of the problems that the Honourable Member has raised. The penetration of sport by major business interests does certainly pose a threat to the very nature of European sport.

For this reason, when the Commission is writing its report to the European Council it will take due account of the conclusions of the first European Union conference on sport (the 'Sports Assizes'), which point out that:

Χ sports competitions cannot be regarded merely as a way of attracting an audience or selling advertising,

Χ the integrity and autonomy of sport must be preserved,

Χ there must be no confusion between the role of broadcasters and that of the sports movement,

Χ the media must not either directly or indirectly influence the organisation or scheduling of sports competitions,

Χ the acquisition of sports clubs by broadcasters, which arouses serious doubts - if not outright opposition - should be avoided.

The Commission hopes that this approach will reassure the Honourable Member.

In preparing the report we have borne the Amsterdam declaration in mind, because the Commission has carried out an extensive process of consultation, culminating in the sports conference.

The report will be the subject of a Commission Communication to the Parliament and Council, and will be passed on to the Helsinki European Council. The Commission will be presenting it to Parliament beforehand.

 

Question no 38 by Christopher Heaton-Harris (H-0538/99)
 Subject: European Audiovisual Observatory
 

Can the Commissioner provide evidence that the European Audiovisual Observatory represents a good use of Community funds?

How often does the Commission itself use the Observatory and for what particular tasks?

Finally, how does the Commission envisage the future management and function of the European Audiovisual Observatory?

 
  
 

The Observatory is a public institution with the tasks to collect economic and legal information from various international sources and to assemble them in an organised and comprehensive way. I believe that these tasks are effectively fulfilled and that the return on the Commission’s participation in terms of support for the audio-visual industry of the Community, notably the SMEs, is positive.

Consultation of the Observatory publications, notably the ‘Yearbook’ and the legal newsletter ‘Iris’ is common practice in the Commission. In case the Community participation in the Observatory be discontinued, the Commission would be obliged to collect on a commercial basis the same information from several different sources. This procedure would prove time consuming and very expensive.

Observatory’s advice has also been sought on several occasions, in the context of on-going contracts; in particular, in the fields of employment, film-financing schemes, international trade statistics, statistical methodologies, market trends in the Community and other areas.

For the future, the activity carried out with the Observatory will increase, notably in relation to two specific areas: the implementation of a statistical information structure under EUROSTAT, and the preparation of GATS 2000 negotiations.

The active participation of the Commission in the Observatory will allow it to optimise the complementarity of the tasks carried out by EUROSTAT and the Observatory itself. Concerning the forthcoming GATS 2000 negotiations, the Commission wishes to stress that it is planning to make full use of the small but professional and flexible structure of the Observatory in order to collect economic and juridical information on the trade partners as well as specific aspects of the Community industry.

 

Question no 39 by Konstantinos Alyssandrakis (H-0542/99)
 Subject: The Acropolis Museum
 

Following the emergence of a broad popular movement to save the cultural heritage of Greece and Europe, and in particular the Acropolis in Athens, one of the most important historical monuments of mankind, a procedure was launched to build an Acropolis museum to house the masterpieces of art and world culture which are found on the Acropolis and in the museums of Europe. The results of the international competition held many years ago which led to the beginning of construction work on the museum are now being questioned by many experts as being outdated; the site chosen is also deemed unsuitable owing to a shortage of space and difficult access for visitors. The government’s decision not to have a complete fire safety system installed - owing to the presence of museum security guards - raises further questions about how this museum, which will house works of art of inestimable value and receive millions of visitors, will function.

Will the Commission say what initiatives and measures it intends to take to ensure that the museum that is eventually built is worthy of the exhibits it houses and provides full protection for these exhibits and complete safety for visitors?

 
  
 

The Commission recognises the great interest and benefit that the construction of the new Acropolis museum has in European cultural heritage terms. However, the Commission cannot intervene in this matter as, according to Article 151 (ex. Article 128) of the EC Treaty, the protection of cultural heritage is the exclusive responsibility of the national competent authorities.

The Commission is not aware of all the facts/problems surrounding the construction of the new Acropolis Museum. In the context of the regular contacts with the Hellenic competent authorities, the Commission will raise the matter and request further information on the subject in question.

Within the remit of its competences, the Commission would certainly be willing to assist the national competent authorities in this matter should the latter make a request to that effect.

 

Question no 45 by Riitta Myller (H-0520/99)
 Subject: Tacis Regulation currently being drafted; coordinating the TACIS-CBC
 

Developing good relations with Russia is one of the priorities of the European Union’s foreign and security policy. Our aim is to strengthen cooperation between the Union and Russia, which will also promote the attainment of the objectives of the Nordic-dimension policy. The revision of the Tacis Regulation, which is important for the Union’s policy on Russia, is now in its final stages, and it is likely to stress the importance of cross-border cooperation. At the same time, something needs to be done about the problems of coordination between the Interreg Community initiative and the Tacis-CBC programme. The current practice has proven unreasonably complex, as projects have had to pass through the administrative procedures of two separate programmes. In the new Tacis Regulation, how will the Commission ensure effective coordination between the Tacis-CBC programme and the Interreg Community initiative? Will the Commission propose that the two funding instruments be merged administratively, so that there is a single procedure for taking decisions on projects?

 
  
 

The Commission fully supports effective coordination between all relevant Community policy instruments as part of the Community policy on the Northern Dimension.

Already under Tacis, cross-border cooperation projects are closely examined to ensure coherence between all projects receiving support from the Community. A good example is the Special Action for the Baltic Region, for which the European Parliament allocated a budget of € 10 million in 1999, and for which projects selected for support from Tacis complement those supported by Interreg and Phare, to the benefit of the region as a whole.

However, the House will appreciate that there are sound legal and policy reasons for the differences between the three schemes. Phare and Tacis programmes operate on an annual budget cycle and have specific aims relating respectively to Community accession and economic transition. On the other hand, Interreg operates with the multi-annual budget cycle used for the structural funds. Its aim is to promote cooperation between Member States and their neighbours outside the Community. In addition, the implementation of these policies depends on the specific situation and the needs of the countries involved. Against this background, the Commission does not believe that it would be appropriate to merge the administrative arrangements of Tacis and Interreg as the honourable Member suggests.

This should not, however, be a barrier to effective cooperation between Tacis and Interreg. On the contrary, the Commission’s proposals for the new regulation on cooperation with the Newly Independent States underlines the importance of effective cross-border action. The Commission intends vigorously to pursue this type of joint financing by making use of the flexibility provided by the Interreg and Tacis programmes.

 

Question no 46 by John Walls Cushnahan (H-0535/99)
 Subject: Policy Planning and Early Warning Unit
 

In the light of recent events in East Timor, will the Commission give an assurance that the establishment of a policy planning and early warning unit, as envisaged under the Amsterdam Treaty, will be given top priority? Furthermore, will the respective parliamentary committees be provided with the relevant analyses, recommendations and strategies on potential crises?

 
  
 

The establishment of the Policy Planning and Early Warning Unit (PPEWU) within the Secretariat General of the Council, as foreseen by the Amsterdam Treaty, falls within the scope of competence of the Council.

The Amsterdam Treaty provides for an appropriate cooperation between the PPEWU and the Commission which, like the Member States, has the right to make proposals concerning the Unit’s work. The Commission is ready for and looks forward to a close cooperation with the PPEWU, not least in order to strengthen the Union’s capacity for preventive action in the field of CFSP.

 

Question no 50 by Pat the Cope Gallagher (H-0502/99)
 Subject: Review of the Common Fisheries Policy
 

Will the Commission state whether or not it has any plans to carry out more intense consultations with the fishing industry in the run-up to the review of the Common Fisheries Policy?

 
  
 

As you know, the Commission has just completed the most comprehensive consultation exercise ever conducted within the framework of the Common Fisheries Policy, in order to prepare the 2002 Review of this policy. This consultation included a questionnaire sent to 350 organisations throughout the Community and 30 regional meetings organised in the Member States.

The fishing industry played a pre-eminent role in these consultations. For its part, the Advisory Committee for Fisheries decided to reflect through a specific ad hoc working group on the issues raised by the Common Fisheries Policy after 2002 and produced a report on its conclusions in June 1999. It is, of course, the Commission’s intention to continue to involve the fishing industry closely with the review process in the future.

 

Question no 51 by Gorka Knörr Borràs (H-0482/99)
 Subject: Non­compliance with Regulation 1239/98 on a reduction in and ban on the use of drift­nets
 

The Luxembourg Council of Ministers of June 1998 agreed to ban the use of drift-nets for tuna fishing from 1 January 2002. By adopting Regulation 1239/98(1), it also agreed on a minimum reduction of 40% in the number of vessels allowed to use them for the year 1998, and that lists of those vessels authorised to use them must be drawn up annually.

Given the blatant non-compliance with this regulation, the delays in communicating lists, the increase in the number of vessels using these nets, the harm to the tuna fishing industry and the marine ecosystem, the serious economic repercussions for fishermen in the north-west Bay of Biscay and the total lack of response from the EU to the recommendations of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) in relation to the overfishing of this species, what measures will the Commission take to ensure strict compliance with the regulation's provisions?

When does the Commission intend to incorporate the ICCAT's recommendations into Community law?

 
  
 

The Member States concerned have provided the Commission with the information specified in article 11 b, paragraph 4 of Regulation (EC) 894/1997(2).

According to the information provided by the Member States, the requirement stipulated in article 11, paragraph 3 of Regulation (EC) 894/97 seems to have been respected. Within the scope of the checks carried out under article 29 of Regulation (EEC) 2847/93, the Commission shall check the data provided by the Member States for the period 1995-1997.

As regards the transmission of data to ICCAT, the Commission has already sent ICCAT the list of vessels received from the Member States concerned.

Question no 52 by María Izquierdo Rojo (H-0485/99)
 Subject: Negotiation of a fisheries agreement with Morocco
 

Will the change in the Commissioner responsible for fisheries, the timing of the recent crisis and the appointment of the new Commission have an adverse effect on the negotiation of the fisheries agreement between the EU and Morocco? Will it be possible to negotiate a new agreement in time, in other words before November, or an extension with amendments to this important cooperation instrument? Will Commissioner Fischler be as tough a negotiator as his predecessor was?

 
  
 

The internal changes within the European Commission have in no way influenced the work of the departments or the political line already established with regard to the relationship in the area of fisheries between the Community and Morocco.

Following the conclusions adopted by the Council of Ministers responsible for Fisheries on June 10, the Commission has had some correspondence with the Moroccan authorities in order to set a date for the opening of exploratory discussions with a view to defining the framework of new cooperation between the EU and Morocco in the area of fishing.

The Commission is waiting for the Moroccan authorities to reply to its last letter of 21 September 1999 to organise an initial meeting.

Aware of the socio-economic and political importance of the EU/Morocco fisheries agreement, it has given absolute priority to this matter, and has set the objective of identifying new forms of cooperation in the area of fisheries with Morocco.

With this in mind, on 13 September 1999 it approved a recommendation for a negotiating directive which was sent on 15 September to the Council, where it is currently being examined.

At this stage, before even starting discussions with the Moroccan authorities, it is premature to put forward hypotheses on the future of EU/Moroccan relations in the area of fisheries and the form they may take, as regards the subject of the continuation of fishing activities after December 1999.

 

Question no 53 by Göran Färm (H-0495/99)
 Subject: Common organisation of the market in tobacco
 

First-time smokers are becoming increasingly younger in the EU. In my own region of Östergötland, the average smoker starts at age 15. In addition to a number of cancers, smoking is also considered to cause or exacerbate heart disease, vascular disorders, osteoporosis and lung disease. It is also thought that smoking in pregnancy is linked to low birth weight and a higher risk of infant mortality.

It is both inconsistent and illogical that, while the EU is campaigning for better health, taxpayers are having to pay the cost of the common organisation of the market in tobacco through the EU budget. What is the Commission doing to ensure that public health and environmental protection standards are given greater consideration and to promote a switch in production to other crops?

 
  
 

The Commission informs the Honourable Member that, in 1996, a report on the joint organisation of the market in the tobacco sector was presented to Parliament and to the Council. This report highlighted the fact that the cultivation of tobacco was an important source of employment, especially in some regions where its cultivation makes a crucial contribution to the maintenance of a viable rural economy.

Following the analysis of the social and economic impact carried out at this time, the withdrawal of the Community involvement in the tobacco sector was dismissed as, among other things, it would have had no effect on tobacco consumption.

Reform of the sector was adopted in 1998. This reform, in force since 1 January 1999, is based on a strategy of improvement of the quality of tobacco intended to better satisfy market demand.

Nonetheless, the reform of organisation of the tobacco market has taken into account other production orientation measures.

The operation of a Community Fund for tobacco research and information was expanded and strengthened by means of a levy of 2% on the bonuses paid to the producer. In particular, this fund had as priority objectives the campaign against tobacco addiction and research into less harmful varieties of tobacco and cultivation methods with a reduced impact on the environment.

The Commission intends to resume the action of the Fund with increased resources, especially in the area of health protection, and by simple and effective management procedures.

In the area of a switch in production to other crops, the reform envisages a mechanism for the repurchase of quotas. In addition, within the framework of the new rural development policy, Member States may schedule measures for the period 2000 to 2006 for the conversion of tobacco-growing areas.

 

Question no 54 by Paul Rübig (H-0510/99)
 Subject: Barley prices and EU enlargement
 

World market prices for barley continue to differ from prices on the internal market. Export refunds are therefore granted under the CAP for exports to third countries.

What trend is expected to be seen in barley prices within the European Union in the next few years, in particular in connection with exports to countries applying for accession, taking account of the pre­accession strategy and the provisions of Agenda 2000?

 
  
 

The current forecasts show that, over the next few years, there will be intervention stocks of barley within the Community. The consequence of such a situation is that the price of barley would be situated around the intervention price and possibly below. This means that, following the Berlin decisions on Agenda 2000, the price of barley will go down from today’s intervention price of EUR 199/t to EUR 110/t in marketing year 2000/2001 and to EUR 101/t as from marketing year 2001/2002.

It is too early to speculate on the possible development of exports to candidate countries following pre-accession strategy. Indeed, the state of play with candidate countries is at a pre-negotiation stage. This means that the main activity at the moment is to examine the current status and developments.

In the short term, what can be said, however, is that certain candidate countries will try to gradually align their cereals prices with Community prices.

In the long term a further element that will influence trade between the Community and candidate countries will be the outcome of the next WTO Round. Here again, as the next Round is yet to begin, it is much too early to have a precise idea of the changes which may take place.

 

Question no 55 by Jan Mulder (H-0518/99)
 Subject: Promotion of fruit and vegetables and accession of CEECs
 

Sales of fruit and vegetables within the European Union and to third countries have shown a downward trend in recent years. In the 2000 budget an amount of EUR 50 million has been allocated for the payment of export refunds. The cost of administering such refunds is high in relation to the amount earmarked for them, and there are also doubts about the importance of the refund. Might the Commission consider abolishing the refunds and spending the money saved in this way on promoting fruit and vegetables within and outside the Union?

In the run-up to the accession of the CEECs, there has been some talk of a zero option for a number of product groups (which would mean no import duties in trade between the EU and the CEECs). In the Commission's view, is this a realistic option, and in which sectors should it apply?

 
  
 

For many years now, the scheduled budget for export refunds has not been used in full, due to the reduction in refund rates. These levels are currently fairly stable and vary, from one product to the next, between 20 euros/t and 100 euros/t, i.e. at a level which is far higher than the administrative costs engendered by the management of this measure.

The Commission does not envisage abolishing refunds in the fruit and vegetable sector. However, it is favourable, in principle, to the promotion of some fruits and vegetables in third countries. With this in mind, the Commission has presented to Parliament and the Council a proposal for a Regulation applicable horizontally to establish a promotion campaign in third countries. This proposal has already been favourably received by the Parliament. Furthermore, Community participation in the promotion of apples and citrus fruits is already in force.

From the point of view of our exports, the “double zero” option involves cancelling export refunds to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe at the same time as import rights into the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. In the fruit and vegetable sector, this option, which is a priori favourable to exports, is under review as regards apples and tomatoes. The Commission, after receiving the go-ahead from the Council, has just initiated negotiations with the countries of Central and Eastern Europe in line with this.

 

Question no 56 by Eluned Morgan (H-0522/99)
 Subject: Agriculture in Wales
 

Does the Commission foresee any difficulties with the possible introduction by the Welsh Assembly of the calf processing scheme and the cull ewe disposal scheme in Wales?

 
  
 

First of all, let me make it clear that, in respect of the Community, the Treaty procedures state that it is in the power of the national governments to request the introduction of such measures. Having said that, it should be distinguished between both measures for which the Commission is requested to give its opinion.

Concerning the Calf Processing Scheme, until the end of December 1999, the UK government could reactivate this premium of its own accord, at the level provided for in the relevant Commission Regulation, or at another rate to be decided by the Commission. Regarding a separate regional application of this measure only in Wales, it must be said this is not possible under the current basic beef market Regulation.

In respect of the Cull Ewe Disposal Scheme, the Commission will consider proposals for national schemes to solve specific problems of the sheepmeat sector in the Member States. Those programmes, however, must comply fully with the treaties and the legislation.

The Commission has not received any information yet on a Cull Ewe Disposal scheme for Wales and making any statements on an unknown programme would therefore be premature. The Commission would draw conclusions only after a sound, in-depth evaluation of such a programme.

It must be underlined, nevertheless, that any programme coming from the Member States must be compatible with free competition and national aid rules both within the Member State’s geographical areas and within the whole Community.

In addition, it should be noted that the Commission has already supported Wales and Community farmers during the last weeks through two specific measures (private storage aid and payment of the second advance of the ewe premium, see background note).

 

Question no 57 by Struan Stevenson (H-0523/99)
 Subject: Crisis in EU agriculture
 

The crisis in the agricultural industry across the EU has been particularly severe in the UK, where farmers are experiencing the worst recession for over 60 years. For example, a recent National Farmers Union (NFU) survey of more than 5000 British farmers showed that incomes for many farmers have fallen below the poverty line with little or no chance of recovery. Even recent emergency aid packages announced by the UK government are being seen by many as too little too late.

In the light of these alarming statistics, what future does the Commission envisage for agriculture in all corners of the European Union and does the Commission predict a viable future for British farmers?

 
  
 

The Commission thanks the Honourable Member for its question that keeps in mind the very difficult situation for farmers in the UK, particularly livestock farmers. However, it is wrong to extrapolate this situation across the whole of EU agriculture.

There are some particular reasons why the present UK situation is so difficult. In each case the European Community has stepped in with support and substantial assistance.

Firstly, the GBP/Euro exchange rate. Farmers that suffer as a result of unfavourable exchange rate movements after the creation of the Euro benefit from agrimonetary compensation. The Commission is glad to see the UK government taking this up. Fifty percent of the budget foreseen for this aid in 2000 will go to the UK.

During the devastating BSE crisis, the Commission has substantially supported the UK authorities in their efforts to safeguard the food chain, to eliminate the disease and to persuade importers to once again have confidence in UK beef.

The UK sheep sector is under particular pressure at this moment and only this month the Commission agreed to a request from the UK authorities to open private storage for British lamb.

In Agenda 2000 the Commission has tried to further develop the framework in which farming and rural areas are better integrated and can consequently flourish. The above examples serve to illustrate that wherever problems occur in the farming industry within the Community, the Commission takes notice and is willing to step in to help.

 

Question no 58 by Brian Crowley (H-0529/99)
 Subject: Adequate funds for the new LEADER Programme
 

In view of the success of the LEADER Programme, will the Commission give a firm commitment that funding for the new programme will be increased and that information on the programme and new initiatives will be widely disseminated?

 
  
 

The Commission welcomes and shares the Honourable Member’s positive assessment of the LEADER Community Initiative for rural development. The overall budget for the 3 Community Initiatives (INTERREG, EQUAL, and LEADER+) for the period 2000 – 2006 was fixed at the Berlin European Council in March at EUR 9.75 billion. (The fourth Initiative, URBAN, was added subsequently by the Parliament and has separate financial arrangements). On 1 July 1999, the Commission agreed the breakdown of the overall budget at European level between the Initiatives, in respect of certain criteria also established at Berlin.

The financial allocation for LEADER+ was agreed as EURO 2,020 million. This figure represents an increase in absolute terms for the period 2000 – 2006 as compared to the allocation of EUR 1,755 million for LEADER II. The Commission considers that, at a European level, this envelope should be sufficient to launch an ambitious new Initiative for rural development, able to build on the success of LEADER I and II.

It is the Commission’s firm intention to ensure that information on LEADER+ is widely disseminated to all interested parties, as requested by the Honourable Member.

The Commission will, in the coming weeks, approve draft guidelines addressed to the Member States for each of the 4 Community Initiatives. These draft guidelines will be forwarded to the Member States for discussion and opinion – in the case of LEADER+ within the Management Committee for Agricultural Structures and Rural Development. At the same time, the guidelines will also be sent to the European Parliament, the Committee of the Regions and the Economic and Social Committee for information. Once these procedures have been completed, the guidelines will return to the Commission for final adoption, hopefully before the end of the year, and will then be published in the Official Journal. The Commission also intends to ensure details of LEADER+ are circulated to potential beneficiaries and all other interest groups in both printed and electronic form, via the LEADER European Observatory.

 

Question no 59 by Efstratios Korakas (H-0545/99)
 Subject: Devastating effect of new quotas and co­responsibility levies for basic Greek products
 

The very small quotas and devastating co-responsibility levies imposed in a provocative and unjust manner on staple Greek farm products have created enormous problems for small and medium-sized farmers, and entire island regions are faced with depopulation. The implementation of the new regulation on olive oil which is an important national product for Greece - olives are the only crop grown in many barren and island regions – will seriously erode olive growers' incomes following the sharp cut in prices (by some 40% over the last few years) and the reduction of some 50% in subsidies.

Will the Commission say what measures it intends to take to ensure that the subsides are paid in full to olive growers and whether it intends to change the general thinking behind quotas so as to prevent the disappearance of small and-medium sized farmers and the depopulation of the countryside?

 
  
 

The Commission does not share the analysis of the Honourable Member regarding the consequences of the application of budgetary stabilisers as far as the olive oil sector is concerned.

The problem of olive growers’ income is principally related to a level of production of olive oil which has a tendency to exceed the capacity which the market can absorb. In the past, the principle of a maximum guaranteed quantity at a level of 1,350 tonnes for the entire Community and the existence of a parallel programme of aid for small producers lead to some abuses. When the aid programme was modified in June 1998, the maximum guaranteed quantity at Community level was, firstly, increased and, secondly, distributed among olive-producing Member States. Greece was allocated 419,529 tonnes of olive oil, which is higher than the average for the previous five programmes, which was less than 400,000 tonnes. At present, for subsidies to fall below 50%, it would be necessary for olive oil production in Greece to greatly exceed 600,000 tonnes, which would not seem compatible with its current production potential.

 

Question no 60 by Richard Graham Corbett (H-0462/99)
 Subject: Circus Coliseo
 

Is the Commission aware of the activities of the Circus Coliseo, an Italian circus currently circulating in Spain on Dutch number plates, which keeps its animals in appalling conditions and seems able to take advantage of the single European market to move from one Member State to another and so avoid action by the authorities?

Does the Commission agree that the protection afforded by the zoos directive should be extended to animals in circuses, especially as the latter can more easily move from one Member State to another to avoid national inspection?

 
  
 

The Commission is not aware of the activities of the Circus Coliseo in Spain.

The Commission supports the objective of ensuring a high protection of animals and deplores all forms of cruelty to animals. However, matters of animal welfare remain of national competence.

The aim of the “zoos-directive” is to ensure that zoos adequately fulfil their important role in the protection of wild fauna and biodiversity. It does not seem to be appropriate to extend this directive, based on article 175 (ex Article 130 S) of the EC treaty concerning the protection of the environment, to cover animal welfare issues in circuses.

 

Question no 61 by Maj Britt Theorin (H-0472/99)
 Subject: Women's rights and equality
 

Article 3(2) of the Amsterdam Treaty stipulates that equality must be a feature of all areas of policy. To achieve that goal, budget resources must be earmarked for a fifth action programme and specific, measurable targets set for equality. Targets may be set, for example, by measuring the percentage of women making up the labour force and the unemployed, by assessing the extent to which the equal pay directive is being implemented and measuring the percentage of women on decision-making bodies. The best three countries should then be selected as targets to be achieved by the Member States through their own action programmes.

What does the Commission intend to do to promote the adoption of a fifth action programme with sufficient budget resources and a fixed timetable and what measures will the Commission take to set specific, measurable targets for equality?

 
  
 

As the Honourable Member of the Parliament points out in her question, the Treaty of Amsterdam has reinforced the Community competences in gender equality by including new articles 2 and 3 which formalise the Community commitment to gender mainstreaming. However, wide discrepancies still exist between Member States as regards gender equality, whether this involves legislation, institutional mechanisms, specific policies or public awareness. The Commission therefore considers that there is still a need for developing coordinated measures under a fifth action programme; such a programme should aim at the strengthening and development of actions already undertaken at Community level and act as a framework programme where all Community policies could effectively work for gender equality. The abovementioned characteristics of the programme will also be reflected in the financial resources which will be proposed for its realisation.

With regard to the second part of the question, the Commission would like to refer to the policy recommendations on national employment policies, which it has proposed for Council adoption, for the year 2000 regarding, inter alia, the issue of equal opportunities. Within this context, the Member States have been urged to reduce the current levels of occupational and sectoral segregation on the labour market (DK, SW, FI), to remove tax-benefit disincentives on the participation of women in the labour market (B, GR, IRL, LUX, NL), or to focus on the gender pay gap (DE, UK), or to reinforce gender mainstreaming (GR, ES, IT).

 

Question no 62 by Marialiese Flemming (H-0474/99)
 Subject: Closure of the Bohunice nuclear power plant
 

The Slovak government has adopted new plans for the closure of the Bohunice nuclear power plant. The obsolete reactor is due to remain on stream until at least 2008 and possibly until 2010. This is contrary to the original undertaking given by Slovakia to close the nuclear power plant in the year 2000.

Will the Commission promptly pass on to the European Parliament all the information it has received from the Slovak government about its plans to close the Bohunice nuclear power plant?

 
  
 

On 28 September 1999, the Slovak authorities officially informed the Commission on the Government’s decision to close down reactors 1 and 2 at Bohunice VI by 2006 and 2008 respectively, ahead of their original design lifetime of 2008 for unit 1 and 2010 for unit 2.

The 1992 G-7 meeting in Munich classified the two reactors as non-upgradeable at reasonable cost, and the Commission repeatedly insisted on their early closure. The European Council in Cologne emphasised the importance of nuclear safety in the context of enlargement and called on the Commission to regularly address the issue.

In December 1998 the Council emphasised that, for the countries which operate reactors which cannot be upgraded to internationally acceptable levels of safety at a reasonable cost, the energy sector strategies must provide for the earliest practicable closure of those reactors, including an agreed timetable for closure consistent with Accession Partnership priorities.

Although Slovakia had taken no international commitments concerning the closure of the two reactors concerned at Bohunice, the Government adopted a resolution in 1994 whereby these reactors would be closed down by the year 2000, after the start of reliable commercial operation of the two first reactors under construction in Mohovce and “no later than 2000”.

The Slovak resolution of 1994 was prompted by the conditionality to obtain an EBRD loan. This loan was not taken up. This tentative closure date was dependent on the completion of the Mohovce nuclear power plant, which faced a number of delays. In view of these facts, the 1994 resolution was substantially amended by the current Government, following a gradual safety upgrading of units 1 and 2 with a view to get a license for operation until the end of the design lifetime, i.e. 2008 for unit 1 and 2010 for unit 2, or even beyond.

This important decision that the Slovak Government has now taken comes after a period of intense and fruitful dialogue between the Commission and the Slovak authorities. The European Commission welcomed the officially communicated decision to shut down two reactors at the Bohunice nuclear power plant (units 1 and 2) in 2006-2008 respectively. The Commission considers that, by taking this decision, Slovakia has made an important step in its European integration efforts and has confirmed that the EU accession objective constitutes an overriding political priority.

The Commission will inform the European Parliament on any further developments regarding the closing down of units 1 and 2 at Bohunice.

 

Question no 63 by Antonios Trakatellis (H-0491/99)
 Subject: Enlargement and nuclear safety
 

In view of the common position adopted by Parliament (A4-0088/99)(1), the Council and the Commission on nuclear safety in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe and in particular on the definitive closure of the hazardous nuclear reactors of Kozloduy (reactors 1-4) which cannot be upgraded and in view also of the recent announcement by Lithuania that it would close reactor 1 at Ignalina and Slovakia's intention to take similar measures in respect of the Bohunice nuclear plant:

What is the Commission's position on nuclear safety in the applicant countries of Central and Eastern Europe and particularly Bulgaria, and does it consider that accession negotiations can begin without dates being set for the definitive closure of hazardous nuclear reactors? What immediate measures does the Commission intend to take to ensure that hazardous nuclear reactors (first-generation) which cannot be upgraded close in accordance with the commitments undertaken by the countries of Central and Eastern Europe as part of the partnership agreements and the Nuclear Safety Account? What were the results of the special working parties set up between the Commission and the Bulgarian authorities on the closure of reactors 1 to 4 at Kozloduy, and is the continuing operation of these reactors warranted in view of the outlook for reduced energy demand in Bulgaria?

 
  
 

The Commission has stated on many occasions that those nuclear power plants operating in candidate countries which are not upgradeable to internationally acceptable levels of safety at a reasonable cost should be shut down at the earliest practicable dates in accordance with agreed timetables. This applies to the Ignalina plant in Lithuania, the Bohunice VI plant in Slovakia and to units 1-4 of the Kozloduy plant in Bulgaria. The Commission approach is fully in line with the positions adopted by the Council and the Parliament.

In the case of Kozloduy, the closure dates foreseen for units 1-4 in Bulgaria’s Energy Strategy are not in line with the Nuclear Safety Account Agreement, signed by Bulgaria. The Accession Partnership for Bulgaria requires the establishment of realistic closure commitment in accordance with that Agreement and in its 1998 Regular Report the Commission expressed concern over the absence of such a specific closure programme.

The Commission is willing to assist Bulgaria in the early closure of Kozloduy units 1-4 with substantial additional funding. The Commission continues to work with the Bulgarian Government in order to ensure that Kozloduy units will effectively be closed at the earliest possible time. Early closure is feasible from an energy balance viewpoint, given existing excess capacity for power production and considering realistic forecasts for electricity demand, and a proactive policy for promoting energy efficiency.

In March 1999, the Commission and the Bulgarian Government agreed to set up a Joint Working Group to prepare the ground for an agreement on a realistic timetable for the closure and decommissioning of Kozloduy 1-4, consistent with Bulgaria’s international obligations, as well as on possible accompanying measures related to economic, environmental and financial implications of the closures. This Group has met three times and has had useful exchanges of information and mutual clarifications of positions.

Unfortunately, progress made towards an overall agreement is insufficient.

As I stressed last month before you, no compromise whatsoever is possible on the safety of nuclear power stations. Without a firm commitment on acceptable early closure dates by the candidate countries concerned, I cannot imagine that a favourable enlargement-related decision could be reached at the Helsinki European Council. The Commission is in contact with the Bulgarian authorities and is hopeful that a satisfactory solution will be found before Helsinki. Progress already achieved with Lithuania and Slovakia should show the way.

 
 

(1) OJ C 175, 21.6.1999, p. 288.

 

Question no 64 by Esko Olavi Seppänen (H-0476/99)
 Subject: Barriers to free trans­Atlantic trade
 

It has emerged that the US security authorities require US computer manufacturers and program vendors to produce different products for European purchasers than they do for the US market. Equipment for shipment to Europe must not be capable of as high a level of encryption as that for sale within the USA, and it is said that, in addition, codes are inserted in it which facilitate electronic espionage. Is the Commission aware of this state of affairs, and will it act to defend freedom in this field too, in order that Europeans may derive the same benefit from mass-produced goods as the Americans?

 
  
 

The European Commission has been complaining to the US for a long time about the export control regulations which limit the export of encryption products to third countries and which have hindered the development of electronic commerce outside the US. As a consequence of these restrictions, the Commission has supported European companies to develop their own encryption products which have gained significant market share world-wide.

As a result of European pressure, but also of complaints from US firms which had lost market share because of the stringent US export controls, the US Government has announced that, after a one time review, encryption products of any key length will be exportable throughout the world, except to the “seven terrorist states” listed by the US. The Commission is currently analysing what will be the impact of this announced liberalisation which is linked to the “Cyberspace Electronic Security Act of 1999” to be transmitted by the US President to Congress.

It should be borne in mind, however, that most countries, including Member States of the EU, maintain some form of control on exports of sensitive encryption products, for reasons of national security and to comply with the Wassenaar Agreement. The Commission is currently discussing before the relevant Council Working Group a new EC Regulation on export controls of Dual-Use Goods. This Regulation would, inter alia, significantly streamline controls on encryption products in Europe and considerably facilitate European companies’ trade in these products. The Commission hopes to see the Regulation adopted very soon.

 

Question no 65 by Luis Berenguer Fuster (H-0483/99)
 Subject: Possible solution to the question of state aid for the Spanish electricity industry
 

Speaking before the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on 27 July 1999, in reply to a question on progress on the issue of state aid for the Spanish electricity industry, the director-general for Competition, Alexander Schaub, stated that he was confident that a satisfactory solution would be reached 'in agreement with the Spanish government', bearing in mind that this is a problem which affects various countries.

Given that previously the Energy director-general had objected to this issue being debated publicly, Mr Schaub's reply would appear to indicate that the Commission intends to negotiate with the Spanish government behind closed doors.

Does the Commission expect the decision whether or not to allow state aid to the Spanish public sector to be based on the negative effects for competition or for consumers, or on the outcome of negotiations with the Spanish government?

 
  
 

The Commission wishes to stress that the acceptance or non-acceptance of state aid does not depend on negotiations with any national government but on the application of the Treaty. The Commission approaches the case relating to Spain in the same way as the cases relating to other Member States, with the goal of preventing attacks on fair competition and protecting the end consumer. If there has been no public debate on this in the short term, it is because the regulations do not envisage this, it being understood that recent contacts with the Spanish authorities have shown a real wish to cooperate on their part, which led the Commission to not, at this stage, open the formal examination procedure envisaged in article 88(2) (formerly article 93) of the EU treaty.

Moreover, the Commission does not rule out opening this procedure in the hypothetical event that the clarifications that the Spanish authorities were asked for should not be sufficient to resolve the matter without opening the procedure.

Question no 67 by Mihail Papayannakis (H-0487/99)
 Subject: Environmental consequences of the war in Yugoslavia
 

In view of the Commission's answer to my Question H-0431/99(1) on the environmental consequences of the war in Yugoslavia, will the Commission say whether it has assessed the consequences of the environmental damage (to which it refers in its answer) in the Balkans region as a whole (including Greece), whether it has estimated the cost of repair measures and how it intends to intervene to contribute towards repairing the damage to the environment in the Balkans caused by the NATO bombing campaign?

 
  
 

The Commission has taken a leading role in the broader international effort through its humanitarian office (ECHO) and the Task force for the Reconstruction of Kosovo (TAFKO). The international reconstruction programmes are still being drawn up and it is not possible at this stage to say what the final environmental element will be.

The Commission is closely associated with the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and its Balkan Task Force (BTF). The BTF is performing a rapid assessment of the environmental consequences of the conflict that will be reported shortly to the Secretary of the United Nations. The Commission, along with a number of Member States, is supporting this activity.

The Commission would like to reiterate the point made in its response to Oral Question H-0431/99 by the honourable Member during Question Time at Parliament’s September 1999 part-session(2) that the preliminary assessment financed by the Commission found no evidence of large-scale ecological catastrophe. The Commission would add that the analysis covered a number of countries in the Balkan region. They were the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, Albania, Bulgaria, Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Romania.

Question no 68 by Carlos Bautista Ojeda (H-0490/99)
 Subject: New census in Spain and its implications for the management of Community policies relating to Andalucia
 

The data used in Spain for carrying out a wide range of statistical, accounting and management calculations are still based on the population census carried out in 1988. Since then the population of the Andalucia region has grown to approximately 350,000 inhabitants, introducing a new variable significantly affecting the results of such calculations.

In view of the fact that this may have an effect on the way Community policies are implemented and that the Statistical Office of the European Communities (Eurostat) uses data supplied to it by the Spanish authorities, can the Commission say if it still uses data from the census carried out in Spain in 1988? Are there any internal rules within Eurostat to ensure that such data is regularly updated?

Is the Commission aware that the use of out-of-date data may distort the calculation of the allocation of aid provided within the framework of Community policies?

 
  
 

All Member States, through their national office for statistics (the INE in Spain), send the Commission, on an annual basis, updated information for NUTS levels 2 and 3 (Autonomous Communities and provinces in Spain).

The latest available data are for 1996. They are stored in the Eurostat’s NewCrono/Regio database which can be accessed by any interested users.

The Commission regularly uses these data.

 

Question no 69 by Marit Paulsen (H-0493/99)
 Subject: Animal welfare as a public health issue
 

The debate on antibiotics in animal feed revealed that there is a link between animal welfare and public health. Proper treatment of animals results in better food and therefore a healthier population.

Is the Commission prepared to promote animal welfare as an aspect of public health?

 
  
 

The quality equation that defines the balance between Public Health matters and the farming of animals is currently under discussion and analysis at Commission level.

The actual shifting of the responsibility for animal health and animal welfare from the General Directorate on Agriculture to the General Directorate on Health and Consumer Protection has highlighted the intention to give, first of all, answers to define the relationship between farm animal health and animal welfare and, on the other hand, product quality.

Many studies on consumer demand show us that the definition of quality for animal products has widened to include factors such as hygiene and safety, nutrition, traceability, and quality of the production environment.

Farm animal health and welfare are today decisive elements for the definition of product quality in the light of the new emphasis given by the consumers to these elements.

The Commission is aware that it therefore becomes crucial to better define the relationship between animal welfare and product quality and understand the many factors that can influence public health policies at Community level.

 

Question no 70 by Gerard Collins (H-0500/99)
 Subject: Improving safety on roads
 

One of the priorities identified by Commissioner Palacio in relation to EU transport policy is to reduce the adverse impact of transport on society. This included the question of safety.

Will the Commission bring forward a Green/White Paper on the question of safety and consult widely in advance of such an initiative?

 
  
 

In April 1997 the Commission published a Communication on “Promoting Road Safety in the EU – The programme for 1997-2001”.(1)

When this Communication was debated in Parliament, the Commission was asked to produce a progress report.

This report is in an advanced stage of preparation and will be submitted to Parliament, the Council, the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions for their opinion.

The report not only analyses past actions, but proposes a list of short and medium term priorities on the basis of cost effectiveness and casualty reduction potential.

Question no 71 by James (Jim) Fitzsimons (H-0504/99)

Is the Commission aware, furthermore, that two shipments of the fuel rods are currently on their way by sea to Japan and that a third shipment has been delayed due to the alert? What assurances can the Commission give that it is investigating the alert and that it will take the appropriate action to allay public fears, including moves to close down the Sellafield complex?

 
  
 

The Commission is aware of the investigations concerning allegations of irregularities in quality control procedures of manufactured nuclear fuel.

The Commission is also informed of the export of nuclear fuel from Sellafield to Japan and is aware of the fact that a further export is under preparation.

Question no 74 by Peter William Skinner (H-0508/99)
 Subject: Food agency
