Question no 75 by Michael Cashman (H-0509/99)
 Subject: Commission responsibilities/Food agency
 

Commissioner Byrne is responsible for consumer safety and health and Commissioner Wallström is responsible for the environmental impact of GMOs. However, Commissioner Liikanen is to be responsible for regulating the food industry, the cosmetics industry, the biotechnology industry and the pharmaceutical industry (including the Medicines Agency). Such a confusion of responsibility has hampered clear decision-making in these areas in the past. How will the Commission deal with this problem?

 
  
 

The Commission will adopt by the end of this year a “White Paper on Food Safety” which will examine all aspects of food safety; namely, scientific advice, legislation, control and consumer information.

The paper will, inter alia, set out the necessary measures and options to complement and modernise food legislation. This will include considerations about a possible food agency. The experience of the European Agency for the evaluation of medicinal products (EMEA) will be a useful contribution to the debate.

As announced by its President, the Commission is presently analysing the different options which could be the basis for the discussion on the eventual creation of such a European food agency.

The Commission has asked a group of independent high level scientific experts to fully analyse the options available and provide recommendations on how best to improve the structure and the functioning of scientific advice.

Clearly, the questions of competence, excellence and independence but also that of the division of responsibilities, in particular with the Commission and the ways to ensure political accountability for such a body, will be key to the Commission’s reflection on this issue.

If a new food agency is established, ensuring full accountability will be of crucial importance. The procedure for designating the director is only one of many ways of ensuring accountability.

Finally, with respect to the question raised on the present division of responsibilities between the Members of the Commission in charge of consumer safety, enterprises and environment, the Commission can reassure Parliament that its collegial nature provides for a clear and coherent decision making process. Services work closely together and consultation of other services is the basic rule before any decision in these areas is formulated by the Commission as a College.

Further consideration of this matter will be given in the future, in the light of the experience gained in the new established set up and of overall consistency.

 

Question no 73 by Simon Francis Murphy (H-0507/99)
 Subject: Food agency
 

Despite the existence of the London-based medicines agency, in reality most decisions are still taken by the Commission, on the basis of advice from the agency. Furthermore, it is the Commission and not the agency which is accountable to the European Parliament. The same applies to the European Environment Agency, which remains little more than an advisory and data-gathering body for the Commission.

Does the Commission believe that the time has come to devolve real power and responsibility from the Commission to the agencies? If not, why not?

 
  
 

The respective roles of the European Agency for the evaluation of medicinal products (EMEA) and of the Commission in respect of the authorisation of medicinal products are laid down in Regulation (EC) No 2309/93. Currently, decisions are indeed taken by the Commission, on the basis of scientific opinions from the EMEA, and after consultation of the Member States through a regulatory committee procedure.

Regulation (EC) No 2309/93 also provides that by January 2001 at the latest, the Commission will publish a general report on the experience acquired as a result of the operation of the current procedures. This will provide an opportunity to consider whether more responsibilities should be devoted to the EMEA, as suggested by the Honourable Member.

Whilst the EMEA is not directly accountable to Parliament, it must, however, be remembered that Parliament, like the Commission and like each Member State, appoints two representatives to the Management Board of the EMEA. The EMEA Executive Director has appeared in commissions of the European Parliament on several occasions in the past and the EMEA is abiding by the European Parliament code of conduct for the preparation of its budget.

The Commission is presently examining the question of an eventual food agency. The experience gained, in particular with the European Agency for the evaluation of medicinal products (EMEA), will certainly help the Commission to define its position in this respect. The “White Paper on Food Safety”, which the Commission intends to adopt by the end of this year, will provide, inter alia, the Commission’s orientations in this area.

 

Question no 76 by Jonas Sjöstedt (H-0512/99)
 Subject: Reduction of VAT for zoos
 

In Sweden, zoos are subject to the highest rate of VAT at 25%. In many other Member States, zoos are taxed as a cultural activity at a considerably lower rate. What is the Commission's view of Sweden's much heavier taxation of zoos than is the case in other Member States? Does the Commission consider that the rate of VAT for zoos should be the same as for other cultural activities?

 
  
 

According to the Community legislation currently in force on the subject of VAT rates, the Member States have the option of permitting a reduced rate for the provision of some goods and services such as admission to zoos. Although Sweden applies a reduced rate to certain services, it has not selected this option for the cases mentioned by the Honourable Member and therefore applies the standard rate.

The Commission is required to periodically review the terms concerned, particularly the content of Annex H to the sixth directive and to make appropriate proposals. It can assure you that this question will be taken into consideration in the framework of a future review of the scope of application of reduced VAT rates.

 

Question no 77 by Laura González Álvarez (H-0513/99)
 Subject: Protecting European shipbuilding from competition from Asian shipyards
 

More than 300,000 jobs at European shipyards, including upwards of 45,000 in Spain, are at risk from the unfair competition practised by Asian shipbuilders, who benefit from substantial state aid and social dumping practices.

What measures does the Commission intend to take to guarantee protection for European shipbuilders from the dumping practices employed by their Asian counterparts?

 
  
 

The Commission shares the concern of the Honourable Member on the subject of the impact on employment in the Community shipbuilding industry of the alleged unfair practices of some Asian shipyards.

In order to ascertain the existence of these practices, a study has been requested by the Commission in order to analyse the situation of the world market. On the basis of this study, which has been entrusted to an independent consultant, the Commission will submit its report to the “Industry” Council in November.

Regulation No 1540/98 establishing the new rules on aid to the shipbuilding sector requires the Commission to present a report to the Council by the end of this year on the existence of unfair practices throughout the world which would be detrimental to the European industry. The Regulation specifies that if these practices were proven, the Commission would propose “appropriate measures” to resolve the problem.

It would be premature, at this stage, to draw all the conclusions of this study, which has not yet been completed. Nonetheless, the Commission would be ready, if proof of these unfair practices were provided, to envisage possible action with regard to the countries accused, within the framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). European industry also has the possibility, in the short term, of presenting a complaint to the Commission, on the basis of the regulations concerning barriers to trade, as soon as it has gathered the requisite evidence. If this evidence is deemed sufficient, an inquiry will be opened immediately.

Although sea-going ships are not subject to import procedures and, consequently, conventional anti-dumping or anti-subsidy rights do not apply to transactions for these vessels, there are some WTO terms which may be used to analyse the alleged practices.

At all events, the Parliament will be kept informed of the Commission’s monitoring report and any conclusions which the Council might adopt on the matter.

 

Question no 78 by Karin Riis-Jørgensen (H-0519/99)
 Subject: Effectiveness in restricting the allocation of State aid by Member States
 

How does the Commission propose to organise its secretariat so that officials working in the area of state aid, in addition to dealing with incoming cases, also have time to investigate cases on their own initiative so as to prevent unlawful state aid - thereby rendering the relevant Directorate more proactive?

Furthermore, how does the Commission propose to combat the form of state aid known as 'ad hoc support', which must be regarded as the most harmful form of all state aids?

 
  
 

The Commission thanks the Honourable Member for her question. Measures in favour of greater efficiency in the monitoring of aid have been proposed by the Commission and form part of the modernisation of the entitlement to state aid. Thus, last July, the Commission adopted three propositions for exempting Regulations for aid to small and medium-sized firms, aid for training and de minimis aid. The adoption of these three exempting Regulations should, in time, result in a reduction of the number of “routine” cases and enable the Commission to concentrate on the most important cases. Furthermore, the Commission wishes to draw the Honourable Member’s attention to the fact that on its own initiative the Commission regularly examines cases of illegal aid.

As regards the second part of the Honourable Member’s question, on national “ad hoc” aid, the Commission is well aware of the potentially damaging nature of such aid and, in line with this, has just adopted, again last July, new and stricter guidelines on the subject of aid for the rescue and restructuring of firms in difficulties.

 

Question no 79 by Gary Titley (H-0521/99)
 Subject: The European defence industrial base
 

The Kosovo conflict demonstrated that, while European defence expenditure is two-thirds of that of the United States, our defence capacity is totally inadequate to support a European defence policy.

What lessons does the Commission draw from this?

What action does the Commission intend to take to ensure that Europe maintains and develops an effective, yet cost-efficient, defence industrial base?

 
  
 

According to preliminary evaluations of the Kosovo conflict, European forces indeed appear to have lacked capacities in certain key areas. Since the defence industry in Europe possesses advanced capabilities, these shortcomings have rather to be linked to the existence of a fragmented production base and procurement system that, inter alia, tend to lead to incompatibilities of equipment and duplication. A more fluid geopolitical situation means that no European country on its own can sustain defence capacities to cover all possible future scenarios.

In its Communications of 1996 and 1997, the Commission proposed that these problems should be addressed by restructuring and consolidation at European level, to achieve a more coherent European defence industrial base. Such consolidation should give rise to a concentration of resources, providing European governments with a more cost-efficient means of procuring technically advanced equipment. These proposals were endorsed by the honourable Member in his report to Parliament.

Similar arguments have apparently prompted Member States to seek consolidation on the demand side via several intergovernmental initiatives, such as the Western European Armaments Group’s (WEAG) ‘Master plan’, the convention for a legal status for the Organisation Conjoint de Cooperation d’Armement (OCCAR) and the ‘Letter of Intent’ (LOI). On the supply side, defence industry consolidation has now reached a level where not only national but also cross-border mergers are taking place.

While the Commission welcomes these developments, their multiplicity gives rise to concern since the benefits of synergies between the various players are at risk. The Commission trusts that the declaration of the European Council at Cologne in June this year, that sustained efforts should be made to strengthen the industrial and technological defence base, will lead to active support for common structures within the EU.

 

Question no 80 by Niall Andrews (H-0528/99)
 Subject: Developing an enterprise policy for SMEs
 

The Commission intends to move from the current concept of a policy on industrial competitiveness more towards an enterprise policy.

What does the Commission intend to do for small firms, as the absence of practical hands-on support for measures for small firms is a continuing weakness of the EU's wider enterprise strategy?

 
  
 

A policy aimed at enhancing industrial competitiveness and an enterprise policy are essentially two sides of the same coin. The new Commission will continue to seek to promote a business environment that would be beneficial to the development of all enterprises throughout the Community. However, enterprise policy must respect the needs of SMEs in particular, which account for most of the job creation. It is important to adopt a horizontal approach to SME policy: the point of view of the SMEs should be taken into account in the design of any Community policy having an impact on the SMEs.

The Commission has already undertaken numerous actions in favour of SMEs. Indeed, the current Third Multiannual Programme for SMEs in the European Union (1997-2000)(1) emphasises the importance that the Commission places on encouraging more people to set up new businesses and on helping existing businesses to compete successfully. A recent evaluation report(2) of the programme gave a positive overall assessment on most of the actions.

Amongst the actions undertaken to support small firms were: improving standardisation for craft products; encouraging the spirit of entrepreneurship through training, and overcoming the specific difficulties faced by certain target groups of entrepreneurs; the launching of a number of studies and pilot projects aimed at identifying the needs of small firms, involving them in trans-border activity; influencing Community policies to include the specific requirements of the sector and of women and of young entrepreneurs in particular.

With regard to future support for businesses and entrepreneurs, the Commission is currently preparing a Multiannual Programme, which is foreseen to begin in 2001. It will be discussed in the Commission early next year. The new proposal will provide an opportunity to assess and review the actions and priorities of the Commission in this field.

 
 

(1) Council Decision 91/15/EC of 9 December 1996, OJ L 006 of 10.01.1997.
(2) COM(1999)319 final of 29.06.1999.

 

Question no 81 by Liam Hyland (H-0531/99)
 Subject: Mortgage penalties
 

In view of the crucial importance of the housing market in all Member States, has the Commission any plans to ensure that house purchasers who wish to avail themselves of cheaper mortgages are safeguarded against severe penalties in renegotiating more favourable loans, particularly for those on lower incomes?

 
  
 

The Commission is conscious of the fact that many consumers who wish to benefit from the fall of interest rates experienced during recent years have had difficulties re-negotiating their loans i.e. because of penalties.

The Consumer Credit Directive includes provisions for early repayment with an equitable reduction in the total cost, cf. Article 8, but these provisions do not apply to mortgage credit as this falls outside the scope of the Consumer Credit Directive. One of the reasons for this exclusion is the undisputed fact that the introduction of a right of early repayment may be problematical for certain types of long-term, fixed-rate mortgage credit, given the risk of a mismatch between the mortgage credit and its underlying funding.

Mortgage credit is currently subject to an experiment in “soft law”: for some time a dialogue between representatives of consumers and of credit industry has been pursued with the aim of reaching agreement on information to consumers on mortgage lending practices; assuming that such agreement may be reached, it will be confirmed by a Commission Recommendation including measures for monitoring the efficiency of the agreement.

The Commission is optimistic that this dialogue will be successful. Until the final conclusions have been drawn, it will be premature to consider how to handle other aspects of mortgage credit, such as opportunities for early repayment, or to consider the need for other regulatory instruments.

 

Question no 82 by Neena Gill (H-0533/99)
 Subject: Establishment of a code of conduct for European multinational companies
 

In its July report on the forthcoming WTO talks in Seattle, the Commission stated ‘the EU and its Member States are firmly committed to the promotion of democracy, the respect of human rights, and the rule of law. This is reflected in their attachment to core labour standards’. Given this stance, does the Commission favour the establishment of a code of conduct on basic labour standards for European multinationals operating outside the EU, and does it believe that such a code of conduct could be extended to cover basic environmental standards as well?

 
  
 

The Commission brings to the attention of the Honourable Member of the European Parliament the code of conduct for multinational enterprises established by the OECD in 1976. Although relatively less known than other OECD Guidelines for multinational enterprises address a wide range of issues, from labour rights to environmental protection through information disclosure and the avoidance of anti-competitive practices. So far these Guidelines constitute the most comprehensive international instrument dealing with corporate responsibilities. They have, moreover, the merit of having been accepted by trade unions and business confederations in addition to the commitments of governments to their implementation. The Commission, together with the 15 Member States, is very active in the current review of this instrument, aiming not only at an ambitious updating of the recommendations, due regard being given to the latest developments in international fora, but also at an improved follow-up mechanism.

The Commission also favours the adoption of voluntary codes of conduct established either by individual companies or by sectoral industry federations and aimed at furthering the respect for core labour standards and at improving the environmental performances of companies operating in third countries. The role of the European Commission in this context is to facilitate the dialogue among all stakeholders by offering venues and occasions for debate.

Indeed a certain number of these codes exist already at the European level (sector-wide codes focused on labour standards for textiles, footwear and retail). Compared to other experiences of individual multinational companies, they have the further advantage of resulting from the agreement between social partners; therefore they enjoy broad support in the respective sector and can be credited with wider credibility as for their implementation.

 

Question No 83 by Ulla Sandbæk (H-0537/99)
 Subject: Transparency
 

As the Commission has publicly stated that civil society should be consulted in the preparation of NIPs (National Indicative Programmes) and country strategy papers, is it prepared to make these documents public?

 
  
 

The Commission shares the opinion of the Honourable Member. This is why, since 15 September 1999, the National Indicative Programmes are publicly accessible on the European Commission Internet website.

Furthermore, within the framework of post-Lomé negotiation, the Commission insists on civil society participating and taking responsibility, and prioritises consultation with the parties involved on dialogue regarding policy and dialogue regarding strategies for cooperation and on their involvement in the implementation of cooperation programmes.

 

Question No 84 by Ioannis Theonas (H-0541/99)
 Subject: Very serious water and soil pollution in Yugoslavia owing to the bombing campaign
 

Examinations carried out by the World Wide Fund For Nature (WWF) on soil and water samples in Yugoslavia in the wake of the catastrophic NATO bombing campaign have revealed the presence of significant amounts of toxic substances including dioxins; the WWF stresses that the pollution poses a direct threat to the groundwater and natural springs, not only within the borders of Yugoslavia, but also in neighbouring countries. The American environmental protection agency claims that one of the substances identified in the region is particularly carcinogenic and in some regions levels of this substance are 15 times above the permitted level.

Will the Commission say what measures it intends to take to minimise the tragic consequences for the environment of the NATO bombing campaign, to prevent the pollution spreading to neighbouring countries and to prevent the population being exposed to soil, products and water containing toxic and other hazardous substances?

 
  
 

The conflict took place in a third country over which the European Union has no jurisdiction and the Commission was not part of the NATO action. Access to the region was therefore impossible during the conflict and remains restricted now that it is over.

The Commission has taken a leading role in the broader international effort through its humanitarian office (ECHO) and the Task force for the Reconstruction of Kosovo (TAFKO).

In the short term, a wide range of environmental damages posing a threat to human health are being dealt with through humanitarian assistance or the military forces on the ground.

 

Question no 85 by James E.M. Elles (H-0546/99)
 Subject: European Commission communication on labour intensive services
 

Many people in the United Kingdom are concerned about the state of disrepair of the country's historic buildings, and in particular churches. These concerns are shared by citizens in most, if not all, other Member States.

A potential remedy for this exists within the scope of the proposed directive for a reduced VAT rate for labour intensive services to which this House has already given, in principle, its support. I understand that an outline agreement on this proposal was reached at the informal meeting of Finance Ministers at Turku earlier this month.

Can the Commission please clarify whether or not, in its view, a Member State could, in principle, apply the reduced rate of VAT provided for in the proposed Directive to building workers and others working on repairs to churches and historic buildings.

 
  
 

The Commission's proposal (on the possibility of applying a reduced VAT rate to highly labour-intensive services on an experimental basis) aimed to put in as few hindrances as possible and leave the Member States the utmost flexibility in choosing the sectors concerned, provided of course that they fulfilled the conditions laid down.

To enter into force the proposal will need to be adopted unanimously by the Council of the European Communities. Reducing the proposed rate will remain an option for Member States and, in any case, it will be for each government to decide whether or not to make use of this rate-reduction option, and if so to what extent.

The Council is actively considering this proposal and endeavouring to complete a restrictive list of the sectors likely to benefit from this measure. Hence it may well be that the services which the Honourable Member mentions are not covered.

 

Question No 86 by Pernille Frahm (H-0547/99)
 Subject: Echelon
 

The STOA report entitled 'Development of surveillance, technology and risk of abuse of economic information' (PE 168.184/Part 3/4) gives cause for grave concern over the current situation in which communications may be tapped without a warrant.

What action does the Commission intend to take for the protection of private and commercial communications against eavesdropping without a warrant by Echelon, for example?

 
  
 

Would the Honourable Member please refer to the answers given by the Commission to the following written questions: E-1039/98 from Mrs Van Dijk, E-1049/98 from Mrs Van Dijk, E-1306/98 from Mrs Muscardini and others, E-1429/98 from Mrs Raschhofer, E-776/98 from Mr Manisco, E-1987/98 from Mr Kaklamanis, H-1067/98 from Mrs McKenna, H-1237/98 from Mr Schorling and H-0092/99 from Mr Theonas.
